thread.title: No-frills Portland State Vikings embark on another marathon bus trip as season rolls on
thread.title_full: No-frills Portland State Vikings embark on another marathon bus trip as season rolls on | OregonLive.com

author: Ken Goe | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: No-frills Portland State Vikings embark on another marathon bus trip as season rolls on
text:
Those no-frills road warriors from Portland State will load up three buses on Thursday for their game Saturday night at Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo.
It will be a two-day trip, give or take 13 hours depending on traffic.
The Vikings travel the same way they do everything else â€” on a budget.
"Of course you dread it," says junior Paris Penn , a versatile skill-position player who might line up at quarterback, receiver or running back. "It's a bus."
Teams at the upper levels of college football charter planes for trips of 700 miles, which is roughly how far it is from Portland to San Luis Obispo.
That isn't possible for cash-starved PSU, which already has bused to Pullman, Washington, and Pocatello, Idaho, for games against Washington State and Idaho State.
The Vikings (5-1, 2-1 Big Sky Conference) won both, so maybe the bus trips aren't all bad.
"You can have your social media, Twitter and all that," Penn says. "But how long is that going to last? Eventually you're going to have to talk to your teammates. That's helped a lot. We're a family this year."
PSU coach Bruce Barnum has planned this trip like a military campaign.
The buses are stopping Thursday for lunch at the Medford In-N-Out Burger, and for the night at a hotel in Concord, California.
"The kids think In-N-Out is like Nike, a cool thing," Barnum says.
He has a History Channel special on Alcatraz cued up to show on the buses, followed by the 1996 feature film "The Rock."
All of that is in preparation for a Friday field trip to Alcatraz, the former federal prison located on an island in the San Francisco Bay, and now a national park.
"Give them a piece of history," Barnum explains. "Get them out of their college football fiefdom."
Well, not all the way out, because Barnum has arranged for a walkthrough practice in the old Alcatraz exercise yard.
They arrive in San Luis Obispo on Friday night, and will have a more formal practice there. They will play on Saturday night, bus back to Concord after the game, and be home by Sunday evening.
The coaches can do their prep work for next week's game against Montana aboard the buses on laptops and iPads.
It's not the normal mode of operation, but necessity sometimes forces innovation. In this case, the camaraderie the Vikings are developing on the highways might be worth the inconvenience.
"Does that matter?" Barnum asks. "I don't know. But I think it's helping our football team."
The offensive coordinator last year, Barnum inherited the job on an interim basis after the school fired Nigel Burton in November following a 3-9 season.
After a 4-1 start, Barnum was given the job outright last week, along with a five-year contract, just before a 59-42 victory over Montana State.
Barnum is a career assistant who spent three decades knocking around the lower levels of college football. He never has coached at the Football Bowl Subdivision level, and so isn't wedded to some the perks that are business as usual on the FBS level.
Take the University of Oregon, which is located roughly 100 miles to the south, where the football program operates out of its own six-story Hatfield-Dowlin Complex.
Among the amenities inside are football locker rooms with ventilated lockers and infection-free Corian surfaces, that come complete with a magic shelf to recharge portable electronics without needing to plug them in.
There are four-foot deep hydrotherapy pools, a barber shop for the players, a players' lounge with foosball tables imported from Barcelona, sofas that recline into beds and gaming stations equipped with PlayStations branded with Oregon's logo.
The Vikings' coaches share office space on the fourth floor of PSU's University Center building alongside the Department of Communication, the Judaic Studies Program, and offices for the School of Business Administration.
The Vikings' locker room is several blocks away and, well, a locker room.
Barnum never has been inside the Hatfield-Dowlin Complex, but he has heard about it.
"They have some cool stuff," he says. "We have a couch in our locker room. It came out of somebody's house when they got a new one. One of the coaches keeps asking me, 'Should we get the players an Xbox?'
"Why? They can do that at home. The locker room is a workplace."
The PSU players don't seem concerned about what their locker room doesn't contain.
Quarterback Alex Kuresa played a season on the FBS level at BYU.
"I think at this level you appreciate things a little bit more," he says. "You can't go in and get a new pair of cleats every day or those type of things. But I think it helps you appreciate the things you have a little bit more."
Penn is a junior from Portland's Grant High School who hasn't ever seen the interior of the Hatfield-Dowlin, either.
"At the end of the day," he says, shrugging, "you can't miss what you've never had."
Besides, PSU has something this year's Oregon team does not: a victory over Washington State.
The Vikings played at FBS North Texas two weeks ago, and they did fly for that game. They were on the bus to the airport after winning 66-7 , and some of the PSU players were following the Oregon-WSU game on their phones.
The Cougars won in double overtime.
"It was fun to see that happening," Kuresa said. "We were celebrating our win. But it was fun to see that happening at the same time."
WSU thumped Oregon State last week, 52-31, leading some to wonder if Portland State has Oregon's best college football team, frills or no frills.
"Yeah, that's what people are saying," Penn says. "We'll take it for now. We're at different levels, but at the end of the day, we did what we had to do against Washington State. We don't play Oregon. We don't play Oregon State. We're focused on Cal Poly."
Well, that and a very long bus trip.
-- Ken Goe
kgoe@oregonian.com
503-221-8040 | @KenGoe
